card.description: Current Missouri Attorney General Eric Schmitt (R) is hoping to snag a U.S. Senate seat in the 2022 midterm election.
card.title: Missouri AG Eric Schmitt Has a History of Helping Communist China

_source.content:
U.S. Senate Candidate Missouri Attorney General Eric Schmitt Has a History of Helping Communist China

Current Missouri Attorney General Eric Schmitt (R) is hoping to snag a U.S. Senate seat in 2022 and has publicly shamed China for its communist ways within the past two years ‚Äî seemingly aligning himself with the GOP‚Äôs ‚ÄúAmerica First‚Äù priorities.

But when Schmitt was a Missouri State Senator, he took quite the opposite posture and looked to partner with China in the hopes of bringing a thriving enterprise to the state.

In 2011, Schmitt was one of the main proponents of Aerotropolis, more colloquially known as ‚ÄúChina Hub,‚Äù a global cargo hub at Lambert-St. Louis International Airport which he believed would increase exports and foreign trade.

Schmitt, who even visited China in the hopes of getting the plan off the ground, said Chicago was ‚Äúmaxed out‚Äù for China‚Äôs needs, and Indianapolis and Cincinnati were cities that hope to edge out St. Louis in making a run for the huge China trade, the Webster-Kirkwood Times reported.

‚ÄúWe need to be a player again,‚Äù Schmitt said. ‚ÄúWe need to invest in our future and our infrastructure. We have a location and transportation assets that can put us on the map again and improve our economy.‚Äù

He partnered with St. Louis Democrats to push the bill forward, one which required the passage of an economic incentives package with major tax breaks, including as much as $360 million in tax credits for developers to build warehouses and establish the international deals.

Ultimately, ‚ÄúChina Hub‚Äù did not receive the support it needed to come to fruition https://www.breitbart.com/politics/2021/09/04/u-s-senate-candidate-missouri-attorney-general-eric-schmitt-has-a-history-of-helping-communist-china/ @RealMarjorieGreene

card.description: Current Missouri Attorney General Eric Schmitt (R) is hoping to snag a U.S. Senate seat in the 2022 midterm election.
card.title: Missouri AG Eric Schmitt Has a History of Helping Communist China

_source.content:
US Senate Candidate Missouri Attorney General Eric Schmitt Has a History of Helping Communist China

Current Missouri Attorney General Eric Schmitt (R) is hoping to snag a U.S. Senate seat in 2022 and has publicly shamed China for its communist ways within the past two years ‚Äî seemingly aligning himself with the GOP‚Äôs ‚ÄúAmerica First‚Äù priorities.
But when Schmitt was a Missouri State Senator, he took quite the opposite posture and looked to partner with China in the hopes of bringing a thriving enterprise to the state.
In 2011, Schmitt was one of the main proponents of Aerotropolis, more colloquially known as ‚ÄúChina Hub,‚Äù a global cargo hub at Lambert-St. Louis International Airport which he believed would increase exports and foreign trade.
Schmitt, who even visited China in the hopes of getting the plan off the ground, said Chicago was ‚Äúmaxed out‚Äù for China‚Äôs needs, and Indianapolis and Cincinnati were cities that hope to edge out St. Louis in making a run for the huge China trade, the Webster-Kirkwood Times reported.
‚ÄúWe need to be a player again,‚Äù Schmitt said. ‚ÄúWe need to invest in our future and our infrastructure. We have a location and transportation assets that can put us on the map again and improve our economy.‚Äù
He partnered with St. Louis Democrats to push the bill forward, one which required the passage of an economic incentives package with major tax breaks, including as much as $360 million in tax credits for developers to build warehouses and establish the international deals.
Ultimately, ‚ÄúChina Hub‚Äù did not receive the support it needed to come to fruition
‚ÄúI actually think it was a win for taxpayers that Aerotropolis died,‚Äù said Sen. Jim Lembke, R-Lemay at the time. ‚ÄúThere was a lot of subsidy money on the line based on a wink and a nod from the Chinese that they would choose St. Louis to fly in cargo.
Before the bill failed, State Sen. Jeanne Kirkton, (D-Webster Groves) said she was leaning toward voting against it. She said:
If this is such a great idea, why isn‚Äôt the free market taking care of it? This will be a big boondoggle if China doesn‚Äôt come along. It seems strange to me that we are jumping to play nice with the communists and will just look the other way at their history of human rights violations.
At a time when we are cutting MoDot, mental health, education, higher education, seniors and health care in this state ‚Äì we are going to find tax credit money to help China land cargo? I think we have obligations that we are not meeting in this state, so why would we build warehouses for China?
However, Kirkton said she ‚Äúadmire[d] the amount of work that Sen Schmitt has put into this idea.‚Äù
https://www.breitbart.com/politics/2021/09/04/u-s-senate-candidate-missouri-attorney-general-eric-schmitt-has-a-history-of-helping-communist-china/

Largest School District In Kansas Will Effectively Expel Students Who Violate Mask Mandate

Students who refuse to wear their mask "properly" four times will be barred from attending class, in person or virtually

National File has obtained an email from English teacher Lizanne Minerva at Northwest High School in Wichita, Kansas, part of USD-259, the state‚Äôs largest school district. The email appears to quote an email from principal Eric Hofer-Holdeman, who declares that students caught violating the district‚Äôs newly-implemented mask mandate four times will be effectively expelled from the school.

In the email, Minerva writes, ‚ÄúI am passing along the expectations for the mask mandate, cut-and-pasting information from Principal Hofer-Holdeman‚Äôs weekly message to teachers.‚Äù In his message, Hofer-Holdeman explains that ‚Äú1st noncompliance‚Äù with the mask mandate will result in a ‚ÄúVerbal warning‚Äù and ‚ÄúIf the student complies with an Administrator request to wear their mask properly, they will be allowed to return to class only if you as the teacher allow it. Administration will assume you do not want the student back in your class during that period unless you specifically write in your communication email that you will allow the student back in that period.‚Äù

card.description: The US administration unveiled a $65.3 billion plan on Friday to arm the nation against future, potentially catastrophic biological threats, whether naturally occurring...
card.title: Biden‚Äôs Science Adviser Warns US Should Gear Up to Face Threats ‚ÄòWorse Than COVID‚Äô

_source.content:
Cont.
Part 2

‚ÄúThe issues include the need to increase overall public health funding, strengthen the public health workforce, eliminate barriers to access, improve data systems, address disparities, improve communications, and improve coordination across federal, state, local, and Tribal authorities,‚Äù according to Eric Lander, Director of the Office of Science and Technology, speaking in a background call with reporters on Friday.

‚ÄúMuch better capabilities‚Äù will be required from the US in the face of future biological threats, he cautioned.

The geneticist underscored that as any next pandemic will likely be ‚Äúsubstantially different‚Äù than COVID-19, the US government would be well advised to start preparing now for such an eventuality.

‚ÄúWe need better capabilities ‚Ä¶ because there‚Äôs a reasonable likelihood that another serious pandemic, that could be worse than Covid-19, will occur soon, possibly even within the next decade,‚Äù said the geneticist.

According to Lander, the current health crisis struck at a time when advances in both science and technology ‚Äúmade it possible to respond much more rapidly than ever before.‚Äù

‚ÄúHad COVID-19 emerged five years ago, we would have had far fewer tools to do this. But, five years from now, we need to have much better capabilities,‚Äù he added.

Lander‚Äôs warnings came as he unveiled the White House officials‚Äô pandemic preparedness funding plan. The Biden administration‚Äôs plan, contained in a 27-page document titled ‚ÄúAmerican Pandemic Preparedness: Transforming Our Capabilities,‚Äù is organised into five ‚Äúpillars,‚Äù addressing different parts of the public health system.

To get the plan off the ground, an initial $15 billion to $20 billion will be required, with the overall cost running into $65 billion over the next seven to 10 years.

In line with the ambitious plan, billions of dollars would be invested in improving vaccines, the public health infrastructure, upgrading personal protective equipment to safeguard against a swathe of pathogens.

Eric Lander urged Congress to allocate the sum in the budget reconciliation bill, scheduled to be debated this autumn.

‚ÄúIf major pandemics similar to COVID-19, costing the US roughly $16 trillion, occur at a frequency of every 20 years, the annualised economic impact on the US would be $800 billion per year. Even for somewhat milder pandemics, the annualised cost would likely exceed $500 billion,‚Äù said the document.

card.title: MAJOR Floods in New York & New Jersey - Sept. 2, 2021

_source.content:
MAJOR Floods in New York & New Jersey - Sept. 2, 2021


The New York area struggled on Thursday to overcome a devastating and deadly rainstorm brought on by the remnants of Hurricane Ida as local leaders acknowledged that the region would need to adjust to a reality in which extreme weather events were the norm.

At least 20 people were killed by the storm, which left more than 150,000 homes in New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania without power. A tornado in southern New Jersey leveled a stretch of houses. States of emergency remained in effect across the region by midday Thursday, as officials sought to get a handle on the unanticipated damage.

At a news conference in Queens on Thursday morning, Gov. Kathy Hochul of New York said that she had received a call from President Biden, who she said ‚Äúoffered any assistance‚Äù as the state assessed the damage from Ida, a storm that she said represented a new normal.

‚ÄúWe need to foresee these in advance, and be prepared,‚Äù she said.

‚ÄúGlobal warming is here,‚Äù said Eric Adams, the Democratic nominee for mayor.

The deluge of rain on Wednesday ‚Äî more than half a foot fell in just a few hours ‚Äî turned streets and subway platforms into rivers. Emergency responders in boats rescued people from the rooftops of cars. Hundreds of people were evacuated from trains and subways.

The rain broke records set just 11 days before by Tropical Storm Henri, underscoring warnings from climate scientists of a new normal on a warmed planet: Hotter air holds more water and allows storms to gather strength more quickly and grow ever larger.

Though the region awoke to a sunny day, New York City‚Äôs subway lines remain at least partly suspended, along with commuter rail service across the region. Airports are open but hundreds of flights have been canceled. Rescues continued, and some rivers in New Jersey and Pennsylvania were still rising.

In New York City, the dead ranged in age from a 2-year-old boy to an 86-year-old woman, the police said. Some drowned in basement apartments in Queens, where a system of makeshift and mostly illegally converted living spaces has sprung up.

Five people were found dead in an apartment complex in Elizabeth, N.J., city officials said Thursday. Another death occurred in Passaic, N.J., where the Passaic River breached its banks and fish flopped in the streets.

card.description: Students who refuse to wear their mask "properly" four times will be barred from attending class, in person or virtually
card.title: Largest School District In Kansas Will Effectively Expel Students Who Violate Mask Mandate - National File

_source.content:
Largest School District In Kansas Will Effectively Expel Students Who Violate Mask Mandate
Students who refuse to wear their mask "properly" four times will be barred from attending class, in person or virtually
National File has obtained an email from English teacher Lizanne Minerva at Northwest High School in Wichita, Kansas, part of USD-259, the state‚Äôs largest school district. The email appears to quote an email from principal Eric Hofer-Holdeman, who declares that students caught violating the district‚Äôs newly-implemented mask mandate four times will be effectively expelled from the school.
In the email, Minerva writes, ‚ÄúI am passing along the expectations for the mask mandate, cut-and-pasting information from Principal Hofer-Holdeman‚Äôs weekly message to teachers.‚Äù In his message, Hofer-Holdeman explains that ‚Äú1st noncompliance‚Äù with the mask mandate will result in a ‚ÄúVerbal warning‚Äù and ‚ÄúIf the student complies with an Administrator request to wear their mask properly, they will be allowed to return to class only if you as the teacher allow it. Administration will assume you do not want the student back in your class during that period unless you specifically write in your communication email that you will allow the student back in that period.‚Äù
The consequences for a lapse in face coverings grow quickly, according to Hofer-Holdeman. ‚Äú2nd noncompliance: Verbal warning with call to parents,‚Äù write Holdeman. Additionally, students will not be allowed to return to their class, regardless of the teacher‚Äôs option. ‚ÄúIf the student refuses to wear their mask properly for the Administrator, then that student will be removed from school until the mask mandate is lifted,‚Äù Hofer-Holderman adds, in italics.
A third ‚Äúnoncompliance‚Äù will result in an ‚ÄúIn-person meeting with admin, student, and student‚Äôs parent(s) or guardian(s)‚Äù and if the student refuses to wear the mask ‚Äúproperly‚Äù in front of the administrator, again, the student will be removed from school.
If the student dares let their mask slip a fourth time, then Hofer-Holderman declares, ‚ÄúStudent may no longer attend in-person until the mask mandate is lifted. Further, their absences will be considered unexcused, learning remotely with NWHS teachers will not be an option. Only those students who are required to quarantine will be allowed to log into Teams and join a class remotely.‚Äù
National File contacted Susan Arensman, the News and Media Relations Manager for USD-259, for comment on this policy and did not receive immediate clarification on whether this was a policy meant for the entirety of USD-259, or simply Northwest High School.
https://nationalfile.com/largest-school-district-in-kansas-will-effectively-expel-students-who-violate-mask-mandate/

card.title: Self-Defense: Good Boy Acquitted on Charges of Shooting at Cops During BLM Protests - Daily Stormer

_source.content:
Self-Defense: Good Boy Acquitted on Charges of Shooting at Cops During BLM Protests

Daily Stormer
September 4, 2021

I knew as soon as I saw his face he was innocent.

Or well, no, I mean ‚Äì he wasn‚Äôt innocent. But he shouldn‚Äôt be punished for shooting at cops. The cops are racists.

It was obviously self-defense.

AP:
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A man charged with attempted murder after firing at Minneapolis police officers in the chaotic protests that followed George Floyd‚Äôs death has been acquitted of all charges against him.

Jaleel Stallings argued self-defense during his July trial, testifying that he fired at the unmarked white van after he was struck in the chest with what turned out to be a nonlethal rubber bullet fired by police.

Stallings, 29, testified that he thought he was being attacked by civilians, had been struck by a bullet and was potentially bleeding out, his attorney, Eric Rice, told The Associated Press on Friday.

Stallings‚Äô case drew new attention this week when an online digital news outlet, Minnesota Reformer, reported on his acquittal and examined the case in depth. The Reformer published body camera footage of his arrest that shows Minneapolis SWAT officers punching and kicking Stallings as he lay on the ground.

A booking photo of Stallings taken after his arrest shows visible facial injuries. Rice said Stallings testified he had a suspected eye socket fracture, bruising and cuts. Court documents say he also had labored breathing after the arrest, which Rice said was likely due to the impact of the rubber bullet to his chest.

When asked if the officers were being investigated or disciplined for use of force, Minneapolis police spokesman John Elder said he can‚Äôt release any information because the matter is under internal review.

Stallings is now seeking the court‚Äôs permission to allow him to release body camera footage that became public evidence during trial, after a prior order in the case restricted dissemination of videos. A hearing on that issue is scheduled for later this month.
